awd_titl_txt: Development of JB Recognition Codes for Manipulation of RNA Structures and Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
RNA molecules have diverse and essential functions in cells, related to their three-dimensional structures. This project is developing a more comprehensive molecular toolbox than is currently available to manipulate RNA structure in an attempt to advance the understanding of their biological roles. This research program serves as a training ground for high school, undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral associates. Training is provided in synthetic, physical organic, analytical, and biophysical chemistry, as well as in molecular and cellular biology. Implementation of this research project is strengthening the ongoing effort to build a Chemical Biology program, at Carnegie Mellon University. The program promotes rigorous undergraduate research training and fosters interest in science among K-12 students and teachers in the Greater Western Pennsylvania area. This interdisciplinary program is providing students and research associates with a unique skillset essential for their future career in graduate schools as well as in industry.

This research project is developing an entirely new set of nucleic acid recognition codes, namely "Janus" bases (or JBs). These bases are capable of forming bifacial H-bonding interactions with adjoining nucleobases on the opposing strands of RNA double helix. In particular, the research is chemically synthesizing JBs and the corresponding millamolecular ligands and evaluating their binding properties with a fluorescence-based assay. The proposed JBs are designed to bind to all 16 possible combinations of matched and mismatched base-pairs, providing a complete toolset for manipulation of RNA structure and function. In addition to their small size and digital recognition, the other benefits of JBs include improvements in recognition specificity and selectivity. Completion of this project will allow the determination of the feasibility of JB recognition and the ability to manipulate RNA structure and function, pertinent to the development of a malleable molecular platform for binding rapidly evolving RNA targets.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research program entitled, ?Development of JB recognition codes for manipulation of RNA structures and functions,? has contributed significantly to the missions of NSF in fostering scientific inquiry, promoting education, and developing entrepreneurial spirit. During the course this work we developed a new class of bivalent nucleic acid recognition codes and showed that they could be designed to any sequence of double helical RNA, or any other RNA secondary structures, in a sequence-specific and predictable manner. Recognition occurs in a highly sequence-specific and selective manner, in favor of the double-stranded RNA over the single-stranded counterpart. The development of such molecules is significant for the manipulation of RNA structures and functions, by combining the superior attributes of small molecules, for being relatively small in size, and oligonucleotide molecules, for being general in sequence selection, based on a well-established set of rules. This research has resulted in seven peer-reviewed publications, in journals such as Nature Communications and Communications Chemistry-Nature, and four patents. In the process, this interdisciplinary research has trained one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and nine undergraduate assistants?many of them were underrepresented minorities. All of them have gone on to have successful careers in graduate programs and medical schools, and in industry. For instance, Adam Simpson Michael-Anthony Simpson, a minority student, is currently pursuing a PhD degree in Environmental Engineering at Stanford, and Ashley Wang, an underrepresented female student, is currently in a medical school at Loyola University. The outcome of this work has also made a major impact on the local economy. The technologies developed from this research were licensed to a startup company in 2019, NeuBase Therapeutics, which in short order became a publically traded company on NASDAQ and is currently employing more than 20 chemists and biologists in the Greater Pittsburgh areas. Overall, the work has made significant contributions to all three pillars of the NSF?s mission.

 


Last Modified: 04/05/2022
Modified by: Danith Ly
